attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Japan, Nara, Nara, Kasugataisha
reviews: Lovely place. Main building under construction tho...

Be sure to put a couple of paperbacks in your back pocket. The deer found out a long time ago that teenagers would leave snacks in their back pockets and thus being bitten on your butt by a deer in Nara is less of an 'if' and more of a 'how hard.'

Tucked into a fold the edge of Mt Kasuga Primeval Forest, with moss covered stones and numerous lanterns lining the path, Kasuga Grand Shrine, is one of Nara's most revered shrines. The entrance is marked by a beautiful Torii Gate. Beyond the shrine's offering hall, which can be visited free of charge, there is a paid inner area which provides a closer view of the shrine's inner buildings.

Know that this is Nara's most popular shrine so there will likely be crowds of people. The shrine is broken down into two sections, an inner and outer section. The outer section is free to anyone who visits and is mainly made up of a few buildings and places to walk. What most people want to see when they go is in the inner section, but you do have to pay to have access. Just know that ahead of time so you can budget accordingly!
Nara, once the capital of Japan, is a pretty little town full of important historical sights (many of them World Heritage sights) in the mountains in the Kansai area.

attractions.name: Toshodaiji
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Japan, Nara, Nara, Toshodaiji
reviews: Not to be confused with Todai-ji, this temple looks fairly similar although it is located on the outskirts of the city. This area was once considered central to Nara and played a significant role in the city's history. Many buildings possess National Treasures and are photogenic. There are far less people here than other temples in Nara which is also a plus.

In the temple of ancient capital Nara, there are few temples that are attacked by fire, and there are many buildings that were built at that time. It is a valuable building in the study of temple architecture, and it is also a unique example of Heijo Gu shrine architecture that is still existing from the imperial court to the lecture hall of toshuden. In order to educate Japanese monks and spread Buddhism in Japan, Emperor shomu invited Chinese monks kanshin and built Tang shokyo Ji Temple in 759. Jianzhen made great contribution to the introduction and development of Buddhism and also made the Tang Zhouti Temple flourishing. It is one of the ties of friendship between China and Japan. The twilight remains a stable roof, with eight columns firmly supported for thousands of years, a model of Japanese Datang architecture and one of Nara's world cultural heritage. The Golden Hall houses the statue of Rosena, which represents the Buddhist view of the universe. The wooden thousand-handed Guanyin statues of the remaining nine Buddha statues are also one of the largest and oldest in Japan. Many of the scriptures and scriptures written by kanezane and the used Buddhist utensils are still preserved, and special exhibitions are held in the Nara Culture Museum and shosoin.

The temple, which is the main temple of the Ritsu sect of Buddhism in Japan, is built by the monk kanshin monk of the Tang Dynasty in Nara City. It is now designated as a national treasure. The temple retains the rich architectural style of the Tang Dynasty and is a symbol of the exchanges between China and Japan.

The word Jianzhen Dongdu should be heard by many people, it is the Tang Dynasty monk Dongdu Japan to spread Buddhism and the advanced culture of the Tang Dynasty. The Tang Zhaoti Temple in Nara is the temple built by the Japanese after Jianzhen arrived, and it has left many ancient structures and monuments.

World Heritage, the central temple of Buddhism in Japan, can be seen from its name and the relationship with the Tang Dynasty. The building is very atmospheric and stable, because it is located in the more remote part of Nara, not many tourists, very comfortable.

attractions.name: Kohfukuji
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Japan, Nara, Nara, Kohfukuji
reviews: Kofukuji Temple is made up of The Eastern Golden Hall and Five Story Pagoda. These are the closest main sights to central Nara, located at the western end of Nara Park. The five story pagoda, at 50 meters, is impressive and is Japan's second tallest. It is a landmark and the symbol of ancient Nara. It was first built in 730, and was most recently rebuilt in 1426. The Central Golden Hall was still under construction in June 2016. You can view the temples for free but the Eastern Golden Hall has a 300 yen entry fee.

Kofukuji used to be the Fujiwara family temple, the most powerful family during the Nara and Heian Periods. This temple was built the same time that Nara become the country's capital in 710. At the time, it was made up of over 150 buildings, but now only a few remain. The most important is the five story pagoda. This is the second largest in Japan and a symbol of Nara that shouldn't be missed.
One of many temples on my life list.
This small temple complex does have a variety of structures available for viewing.  It is fairly easy to do a short walking tour while wandering around the larger Nara area.

If you want to say that there are any attractions in Nara must not be missed, the location is super good Nara Kofuku Temple, basically every visitor to Nara must return to a attraction. The earliest time came in the Zhongjintang in repair, then repaired for a full decade, came a few times in the middle of the repair, this time finally repaired, it seems really powerful and domineering, very beautiful and solemn, compared to the edge of the five-heavy tower lost a lot of color. But to say the most beautiful scenery, must push the night view, the day because the tourists can not feel the quiet temple at all, to the night is quiet no tourists, the experience of the time is too wonderful, it is like the snowed Forbidden City.

attractions.name: Mount Wakakusa
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Japan, Nara, Nara, Mount Wakakusa
reviews: I always wanted to just lay down on the nice grass hill overlooking the city, with a nice and gentle cool wind in a sunny day that will make me forget about life and problems for a while.
The central area of Nara Park will see this small, but not small hill, there seems to be no trees under the mountain, the whole lawn, there are many deer, very peaceful.

Wakakusa is located near the Todai Ji Temple and Kasuga Taisha Shrine, 342 meters high. It is divided into three slopes, from low to high: one, two and three. From the double eye, you can see the whole landscape of Nara.

Moved from Kyoto to Osaka early in the morning and went to Nara deliberately. I wanted to go to Mount Wakakusa first and then play all the way down, but after spending a long time in Mount Wakakusa, I didn't go anywhere else hahaha. After sending your luggage at Nara Station, you can take the loop line at the door. You can swipe the watermelon card and get off at Kasuga Taisha Headquarters Station. After walking, you have seen a lot of deer along the way. The entrance fee of Mount Wakakusa is 150 yen, and the child is 80, which is very, very cheap. If you charge 100 in China, it will be considered kind. As soon as I entered the scenic spot, the child said that he wanted to go to the toilet. The aunt smiled and opened the door to let us out, and told us to come and let us in with the ticket stub. It was very friendly and nice. When I first entered Mount Wakakusa, it was a big grass slope. You can sit here and enjoy the scenery, but it was very windy that day. Moreover, my phone slipped down the slope, and everyone on the slope was watching. It was too embarrassing. Going up again is the first, second and the highest (and the most windy) third. The scenery of each double-meal is nice, very open, and there is also an ancient tomb in the triple-me. The deer will appear randomly, and there will be a bunch of triple eyes. Buy deer senbei at the door in advance and you can feed it. It is said that the deer of Mount Wakakusa are more obedient and less likely to hit people. Except for a few, it is still a bit fierce to be wary of those who have horns or have horns. Back down the original road, there are cherry trees along the way, if you catch the cherry blossoms, it should be more beautiful. If it's not because of the wind, it's really good, you must go to Nara.

From the bottom of the mountain, the mountain is really bare and there is only a lawn, as if there is no tree. The mountain is fenced off for a week. You need to get a ticket. The mountain is not high and suitable for walking. There are many deer under the mountain.

attractions.name: Todaiji Nigatsudo
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Japan, Nara, Nara, Todaiji Nigatsudo
attractions.address: 406-1 Zoshicho | Todaiji Temple, Nara 630-8211, Nara Prefecture
reviews: A quiet and tranquil temple with deer roaming on the fields, Nigatsudo is lovely.

Perched on the hillside above Todaiji, Nigatsu-dō Hall is the silent hero temple of Nara. When I visited early in the morning it was only local paying their respects and a woman chanting prayers. Omizutori, or Shunie, is held here. It is a series of Buddhist repentance rituals that has been held every year for over 1250 years, making it one of the oldest reoccurring Buddhist events in Japan. Nice views from up here too. Free entry.

Nigatsu-do is one of my favorite temples in all of Nara and it's not very well-known to most tourists. The main hall of Nigatsu-do has been designated as a National Treasure of Japan and houses some of the National Treasures of Todai-ji. There isn't a whole lot to do normally except walk around and take in the views, but it's very peaceful. If you can visit in March, be sure to attend Omizutori, the fire festival welcoming spring!
The temple is just about 10min walk from to Todaiji Temple! Be prepare to climb some stairs!

February Hall is one of the important wooden structures in the East Dai Temple, located on the east side of the Great Buddha Hall. This is the building of the Nara Buddhist world specializing in the Eleven Faces Repentance Association (Shu February Association), which is a building for the holding of the Shu February Association, commonly known as the February Hall.

attractions.name: Naramachi
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Japan, Nara, Nara, Naramachi
reviews: The main commercial street of Nara, which is the most distinctive small street in Nara, is a street with a wide range of Edo buildings.

I personally like the peaceful Nara Town. You can take the circle bus to a visitor center near the town, where you can get a free map. Then after entering, look for those small family-style museums, most of which are free.

Quiet small street, here is very suitable for slow-paced travel. There are many small family-style museums inside, where you can see the daily life of ordinary people in Nara. And you can also buy some unique gadgets.

Nara is a city suitable for strolling around on foot. It is a bit old. In the old town area of Nara Town, Japanese-style machiyas have been preserved. The only thing I don't understand is that it is old and deep at 6 o'clock in the evening, and the shops are freshly opened and there are fresh people and cars. I encounter a pedestrian street in Nara Town, and the small shops are very distinctive; the crane machine in the high-speed service area, can you add it to the small one? Interesting

This historic temple is about a 5-minute walk from Kintaiji Nara Train Station, so let’s get to this place first. The temple consists of many gorgeous pagodas and grand halls. The entrance to the compound is free, but you have to pay to enter some of the buildings here. I did not enter those buildings, but took some good photos, and then I went to the nearby Todaiji Temple.

attractions.name: Universal Studios Japan
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Japan, Osaka, Osaka, Universal Studios Japan
attractions.open_status: Tue - Fri 9:30 AM - 7:00 PM, Sat - Mon 9:30 AM - 8:00 PM
reviews: เป็นที่ที่สวยมาก และสนุกมากก ยังจำความรู้สึกตอนไปเล่นได้เลย แล้วก็มีมุมให้ถ่ายรูปเยอะมากกก

Universal Studios Japan, located in Osaka, is one of six Universal Studios theme parks, owned and operated by USJ LLC, which is wholly owned by NBCUniversal.The park is similar to the Universal Orlando Resort since it also contains selected attractions from Universal Orlando Resort and Universal Studios Hollywood.
so amazing to enjoy with family and friends, you can’t enjoy alone, The night lights show is great

I needed to separate my whole USJ experience review because I also have a lot to say about my exciting experience in the other rides of USJ other than the HP ones. I loved the Minions. Yes, I am no longer a kid, but I was still very excited to meet the life-sized minions. Their dance during the Finale show was so much fun! The Spiderman Ride was my absolute favorite because of how accurately interactively 3D it was. The hollwood dream ride was also fun. They have both front-faced and backdrop for the Hollywood Dream ride. I think the Backdrop one is more challenging than the one we tried. I especially enjoyed the Shark ride as well. Overall, USJ made me geniunely happy in 1 day. I basically forgot all of my problems that day, and that's thanks to USJ. ♥️

Went last month, average temperature about 10-19 degree Celsius. Great time to visit, not too crowded but still have to wait at least 80-90 minutes for those popular rides. A must if you are visiting Osaka.

attractions.name: Nara National Museum
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Japan, Nara, Nara, Nara National Museum
attractions.open_status: 9:30-17:00, stop 30 minutes before closing. The closed day is Monday (the next day for the holiday season) and January 1.
reviews: The museum has good presentation and some exceptional statues showing a very fine art. Usually relative quite but may be crowded when there are special exhibitions.

The Nara National Museum is a must-visit. Since Buddhism is so important to the area, it primarily displays Japanese Buddhist art and artifacts. This museum actually has English explanations, which is great! What's really cool is that it was established in 1889 and the museum retains its original building, which in itself is worth the visit.

The Nara National Museum opened in 1895 and is centered on the main building completed in 1894 and Nishi shinkan completed in 1972. The main building was built in the western style during the Meiji period and the Nishi shinkan in the Showa period. The original Todai Ji Temple is exhibited in 5 every year, and it is a collection of treasures collected by shosoin in the hall.
The Nara Park area is a particularly striking museum, with a pool in front that is very open, not very big or very low-key, but it is a very important Buddhist art exhibition.

The Nara National Museum is located in Nara Park. The location is very easy to find. It is a pity that every time I come to Nara, the time is very tight. I have never had the opportunity to go in and stroll around. But this time I finally arranged to stay for one night, but it happened on Monday again. The museum is closed, which is also very depressing. When I went to eat in the evening, I passed by and took a picture of the appearance. After lighting up, it became more obvious in the grass and looked very beautiful. To be honest, Japanese museums like this European style very much, whether in Kyoto, Nara or Tokyo. Many treasures in the museum are now in the Tokyo Museum, so if you go to Tokyo, it is more suitable to go in.

attractions.name: Det Kongelige Slott
attractions.loc_tags: Europe, Norway, Oslo, Oslo, Det Kongelige Slott
attractions.open_status: The Royal Palace is only open to the public every summer and is subject to a guided tour. Opening hours: Monday-Thursday 11:00-17:00, Friday 12:00-17:00, Saturday-Sunday 10:00-17:00, holiday opening hours can be found on the official website; the entire journey is about 1 hour Each group is about 20 minutes apart. English speaking tour group: 12:00, 14:00, 14:20, 16:00.
reviews: very pretty to look at from the outside, just like the rest of the city!
I'm not sure the name is right, but it's good view
I can recomandate the guard change. BUT if you know the guard change in London, this will be a very funny thing for you.

Oslo's Royal Palace was built in the early 1800s on a hillside overlooking the harbor. It's fairly small, as far as palaces go. Surprisingly, visitors are allowed to walk completely around the building and practically up to the front door. Tours are offered during the summer. Plan to arrive during the changing of the guards, a low-key but interesting tradition. Then explore Slottsparken, the expansive surrounding gardens--you can picnic on the king and queen's front lawn.
The palace is on a hill over looking the center of the city. The guards outside, unlike in England, will chat with you and pose for photos.

attractions.name: Vigelandsparken
attractions.loc_tags: Europe, Norway, Oslo, Oslo, Vigelandsparken
reviews: The first stop in Oslo, Norway, is to visit Vigeland Sculpture Park. Free attractions, beautiful environment and reasonable layout. It is named after a famous sculptor. A total of 192 nude sculptures, 650 figures. It took more than 20 years to complete. All sculptures reflect a theme-life and death. Great!

Vigeland Sculpture Park-located in the northwest of Oslo, the capital of Norway. Named after the Norwegian sculptor Gustav Vigeland. There are 192 nude sculptures in the park. There are 650 human figures in all the sculptures, which took more than 20 years to make carefully. All the statues have no explanation, and they do reflect the whole process of life from childhood to old age, which makes people think freely. The park is free to enter. The environment and greenery inside are very beautiful. Many locals spend their holidays here and walk their dogs and babies. It is quite comfortable.

Vigeland Sculpture Park, located in the northwest of Oslo, covers an area of nearly 50 hectares and is named after the Norwegian sculptor Gustav Vigeland. There are 192 nude sculptures in the park, which are shared by all the sculptures 650 statues of human figures, all statues are made of copper, iron or granite over 20 years.
It is such a park with the theme of life. The central idea of all the statues in the park focuses on one theme-the life and death of people. The whole park is like a beautiful picture scroll.

The famous Norwegian sculptor Vigeland takes sculptures of people from life to death as the main body, and forms the sculpture group of the park through four parts: Bridge of Life, Fountain of Life, Pillar of Life and Wheel of Life. Most of the works are nude, made of stone and copper. Covering an area of 80 hectares, there are 192 statues and 650 reliefs. It is the largest sculpture park in the world.

Oslo, the capital of Norway, has a world-renowned sculpture park with the theme of life. It is called Vigeland Sculpture Park.
In 1909, a man named Vigeland who had sought advice from the French artist Rodin at the age of 41. Boldly proposed to the government: Give me a piece of green space, and I want it to be world-renowned. The Norwegian government really fulfilled his wish. Since then, he has lived, lived and lived in this green space, exhausting the rest of his life to independently complete the overall planning blueprint of the park and all the sculpture designs. The park was built in 1924 and completed in 19 years. The park covers an area of 455 acres. There are 150 groups of large and small sculptures in the park, including 192 sculptures and 650 reliefs. Each group of sculptures reflects a theme-life! So it is also called "Life Park"
Vigeland Park has designed four parts on the central axis of the park around the theme of "life", symbolizing the four stages of life, from life to death:
The first stage: the bridge of life. The second stage: as the fountain of life. The third stage: the pillar of life. The fourth stage: the wheel of life. Walking among the group of sculptures makes people feel the joys, sorrows, joys, sorrows and reunions experienced in life. Make every visitor fear and treat life kindly!

attractions.name: Oslo City Hall
attractions.loc_tags: Europe, Norway, Oslo, Oslo, Oslo City Hall
reviews: The Nobel Peace Prize is awarded in Oslo City Hall each year. The art work in the building is amazing!
The city hall is right near to the center of town and also next to the harbor. It serves as a great reference point for navigating the city.

The building too huge and imponent in the city landscape, and not particularly beautiful. However the interior is worth the visit. The painted murals, ceilings and floors are beautiful. The Nobel peace prize ceremony is held in the main room.The entrance is free.
It looks like two brick towers connected by another brick building. Nobel Peace Prize ceremony was held here, making it an Oslo's famous building.
Architecture of The Town hall of Oslo is magnificent.It is the  central of the city.

attractions.name: Akershus Fortress
attractions.loc_tags: Europe, Norway, Oslo, Oslo, Akershus Fortress
attractions.open_status: October 1st - April 30th of the following year: Gate 7:00-21:00, Side Gate 7:00-18:00; May 1st - September 30th: Gate 6:00-21:00 Side Gate Monday - Friday 7:00-21:00, Saturday-Sunday 8:00-21:00; Castle Gate closed in winter.
reviews: This was a great place to set out and explore early in the morning, as it offered phenomenal views of the sea and sunrise (at 10AM in the winter months, so no need to rise super early!) The fortress itself is easily accessible and simple to guide yourself through, I had researched it before my trip, so gave myself a self-guided tour to save a bit of money on my attempt at a budget-friendly trip to Norway last December. The grounds are very quiet early in the morning and it also allows you to get some stunning photos without the large crowds in all of them, so that was a bonus.
Beautiful medieval castle, it wasn't open when we visited, but it's a beautiful spot with great views over the Oslo Fjord.
A great piece of Norwegian history is located at this 14th century castle and fortress. Take a tour on a sunny summer day and enjoy this historic site.

To discover Oslo’s history, head to Akershus Fortress. This medieval castle was completed in the 1300s and has withstood a number of sieges throughout the ages. It was converted into a Renaissance castle and royal residences between the 16-17th centuries.

Such a fun area to walk around!  Even when the fortress's inside is closed, there's plenty to see!  They host races around the fortress grounds... I almost ran straight into people due to that!  It's quite a nice view too.  This is a spot not to be missed!

attractions.name: The National Theatre
attractions.loc_tags: Europe, Norway, Oslo, Oslo, The National Theatre
reviews: Very inpressive theatre, but closed during summer.
Its a bilding thats inpress. Innside and autside its fantastisk.

Beautiful building located right in the middle of one of Oslo's busiest bus/tram and subway stops.  It's situated on cute grounds with flowers, sculpture and fountains for visual intrigue.  Certainly a nice spot to walk by if you don't have time to see a show.

The National Theatre in Oslo, Norway is an ancient building with a history of more than 200 years. The area of the entire theater is not very large, but it is one of the famous European theaters. Some classic opera performances are often staged here, and it is worth visiting.

The statue on the left side of the entrance of the Norwegian National Theatre is the famous Norwegian dramatist and writer Henrik Ibsen. His famous works include "Doll's House" and "The Enemy of the People". His works have played a positive role in China's May Fourth New Cultural Movement. Promote! In the rain, I visited Vigeland Sculpture Park. There are 192 sculptures in the park, with a total of 650 statues.

attractions.name: Nobel Peace Center
attractions.loc_tags: Europe, Norway, Oslo, Oslo, Nobel Peace Center
attractions.open_status: May 16-August 31: Monday-Sunday 10:00-18:00; September 1st-May 15th: Tuesday-Sunday 10:00-18:00. More free opening hours and closing hours are available on the official website.
attractions.address: Brynjulf Bulls Plass 1 | City Hall Square, Oslo 0250
reviews: The permanent collection provides a pretty extensive multimedia overview of Peace Prize laureates’ life and works as well as that of Alfred Nobel. The temporary exhibitions explore themes relating to the prize, currently, there are exhibitions on wealth, the atomic bomb, and the meaning of home.

The permanent collection provides a pretty extensive multimedia overview of Peace Prize laureates’ life and works as well as that of Alfred Nobel. The temporary exhibitions explore themes relating to the prize, currently there is an exhibition on wealth, the atomic bomb, and the meaning of home.
A Must to go place for everyone who is in the town or around. Please don’t miss it and make sure to the the installation of all nobel price winners.

Even though Alfred Nobel is Swedish and the annual Nobel Prize ceremony happens in Stockholm, Nobel Peace Prize is selected by Norwegian Nobel Committee appointed by the Parliament of Norway. The Nobel Peace Prize is awarded in Oslo City Hall each year.
If you will learn all about the Nobel Peace Prize (why this is the only Nobel Prize awarded in Oslo) and Mr. Nobel you have to visit this exhibition.

attractions.name: Oslo Domkirke
attractions.loc_tags: Europe, Norway, Oslo, Oslo, Oslo Domkirke
reviews: This church is stunning. I usually try to make a trip to a local church in every foreign city I visit; this one was worth the wait. Without knowing it, I stumbled into the church in the evening when a children’s choir was performing. It being Christmas time, needless to say, it was magical. I didn’t want to disturb the concert, so made a mental note to return the following day when the cathedral would be empty. What gorgeous architecture. The ceiling of this place seemed endless. It was quiet and peaceful and a perfect place to spend a half hour admiring the design, even if most of the descriptions were in Norwegian.       The church is surrounded by the sweetest yard-light snow had fallen on the ground. I would absolutely recommend this, even to people who are not particularly religious, because it’s hard to overlook the History and architecture in such a massive and beautiful place.

This church is stunning. I usually try to make a trip to a local church in every foreign city I visit; this one was worth the wait. Without knowing it, I stumbled into the church in the evening when a children’s choir was performing. It being Christmas time, needless to say, it was magical. Nice cathedral in downtown, close to the hotel I was staying so I walked by here every day.
Nice cathedral in downtown, close to the hotel I was staying so I walked by here every day.
Oslo Cathedral is the main church of the city.  After seeing a lot of churches around Europe, I don't consider it to be incredible, but it's definitely worth walking by.

attractions.name: Vinwonders Nha Trang
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Vietnam, Khanh Hoa, Nha Trang, Vinwonders Nha Trang
attractions.address: Hon Tre island, Vinh Nguyen, Nha Trang
reviews: Staffs are nice, but a little lack of English speaking skills. Sometimes had difficulty to communicate.

Невероятное место!! Желательно, чтобы вы приехали, как можно раньше и даже в этом случае, вы не успеете все обойти. Можно добраться туда на канатной дороге или моторной лодке. Туда, мы ехали на канатке, а обратно на моторной лодке. При входе парк аттракционов, аквариум, кинотеатр, парк с разными вкусностями. Если зайдёте в глубь, попадёте в аквапарк. Аквапарк экстрим и не у каждого хватит смелости испытать, эти горки, но мне хватило духа. Обязательно возьмите питьевые кокосы-это нечто. Очень вкусный натуральный напиток. Море - сказка. Никаких волн, заходи и купайся. Чуть выше, есть колесо обозрения, парк с фламинго, ботанический парк и ещё многое другое, что, мы не успели обойти. Море удовольствия. Всем рекомендую.

Аквапарк, різні атракціони, 4D кінотеатр з різними фільмами, океанаріум, шоу русалок, шоу дельфінів, шоу фонтанів,колесо огляду, чистий пляж, шоу, різні вистави- все це поєднані в одному місці. Двічі приходила сюди, оскільки за один день майже не реально все відвідати.Рекомендую!!!

Very clever set up. You can choose between peaceful and quiet to loud and busy.The beach was long enough to be alone and if you need company the hotel pools were very accessible. I would recommend the Spa at the Vin pearl Lux the South west side of the island. The night sky was also decorative.
Отличное место для посещения! Советую приежать сюда минимум на 2 дня, так как здесь очень много развлечений на любой вкус

attractions.name: Nha Trang Beach
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Vietnam, Khanh Hoa, Nha Trang, Nha Trang Beach
reviews: Nha Trang is a coastal city and capital of Khánh Hòa Province, on the South Central Coast of Vietnam. It is bounded on the north by Ninh Hoà district, on the south by Cam Ranh town and on the west by Diên Khánh District. The city has about 392,000 inhabitants, a number that is projected to increase to 560,000 by 2015 and 630,000 inhabitants by 2025.An area of 12.87 km2 (4.97 sq mi) of the western communes of Diên An and Diên Toàn is planned to be merged into Nha Trang which will make its new area 265.47 km2 (102.50 sq mi) based on the approval of the Prime Minister of Vietnam in September 2012.
The waves are 1-2 meters when I am here.Swimming is prohibited but many cannot resist it. Swim at your own risk.
Explore the beautiful islands of Nha Trang Bay while in port in Cau Da Port and benefit from the personal touch of a private tour.
food to try in Nha Trang ... it’s really good !!
one of the best beach is south east asia .. clean beach , best sun rise view . recommend 5.30 am to be at the beach for it .. sun rise can also be view if you stay at intercon .

attractions.name: Hon Tre
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Vietnam, Khanh Hoa, Nha Trang, Hon Tre
reviews: Hon Tre Island, just off the coast of Nha Trang, is best known for housing Vinpearl Amusement Park.

No pearl, no nha Trang! It is estimated that all the small partners who travel to nha Trang, Pearl Island will be an important destination, known as Vietnamese version of Disney, really very funny, the whole off-island park is located on an independent island, surrounded by the sea, the environment need not be said, very comfortable! The way to enter the park is in the river, cross the sea cable car or ferry, we are going back and forth, natural selection is tried, the purpose is to feel different scenery! attractions.name: Nha Trang Cathedral
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Vietnam, Khanh Hoa, Nha Trang, Nha Trang Cathedral
attractions.address: 31 Thai Nguyen | Phuoc Tan, Nha Trang
reviews: Nha Trang Cathedral (locally known as the stone church or Nui Church) is the largest church in the city. Open daily from 0830am to 11am

A must do for any Catholics visiting, and even non believers. Beautifully built Cathedral, and a ton of statues of all the great apostles, saints and martyrs of the Catholic Church surround the Cathedral, in addition to a magnificent statue of the Virgin Mary. We even got to witness the the locals praying their rosary at 4.30, and they sang it ! Very musical and beautiful indeed. Catholicism is alive and well in Vietnam !

Built between 1928 and 1933 in French Gothic style, complete with stained-glass windows, Nha Trang Cathedral stands on a small hill overlooking the train station.It’s a surprisingly elegant building given that it was constructed of simple cement blocks. Some particularly colourful Vietnamese touches include the red neon outlining the crucifix, the pink back-lighting on the tabernacle and the blue neon arch and white neon halo over the statue of St Mary. In 1988 a Catholic cemetery not far from the church was disinterred to make room for a new railway building. The remains were brought to the cathedral and reburied in the cavities behind the wall of plaques that line the ramp up the hill.

This church is called nhà thờ chánh ta, Chinese for short, the cathedral, opening time is 8 o'clock, 11 o'clock, 2 to 4 o'clock, no one collects tickets, but there is a merit box at the door, you can voluntarily put some change into it. The small shop at the door 7K one bottle of mineral water, very cheap. The church's photo is OK, a selfie stick and tripod can be produced ～～

reviews: Get your swimsuits and bath-towel from the kiosk Soak your body in Hot Spring temperature mud. Its good once awhile.

There is also a water world inside. You need to make a car to go there. There is no need to line up. The mud wash is completely smooth and more comfortable than a mask. It is recommended to play other items first and take a mud bath at the end. You don’t need to use soap and make a spa for your skin. The only drawback may be the distance from the city. Ctrip tickets are cheaper than buying them on-site. Please attach the picture and do the calculation yourself.
The mud bath, said to be good for the skin, the rest is your free imagination time.
High performance-price ratio, nice scenery, very comfortable, and overall it is great!

The Cham Tower came out and called for a taxi. It took less than 10 minutes to arrive at i-resort. There was a Chinese price list. The ticket is booked on Ctrip. The booked Koike is ¥87, and the front desk retail price is 300,000 dong, so Ctrip's price is advantageous. This price also includes the hot spring pool. Ctrip will send an electronic confirmation number and an appointment code. At the front desk of i-resort, just hand the confirmation number and reservation code to the receptionist, watch her enter the information into the PAD, and it will be OK. There is also a Chinese-speaking receptionist at the front desk. There is a SPA pavilion next to the hot spring pool, which is charged separately. We bought the tickets directly at the front desk and made an appointment. 300,000 dong, 50 minutes. At the entrance of the dressing room, a large towel, a key to the locker cabinet, and a bottle of mineral water will be given to each person with a ticket. Towels are only distributed once, not unlimited times. The cabinet is also relatively small. When you go to the hot mineral mud bath, remember to bring the ticket and collect it. There is a place to hang towels by the pool. The size of the small pool is 1 to 3 people, but when there are few people, it can be enjoyed by one person. When there are many people, I don’t know how to solve it. Next to it is the sun shade, which can be retracted. After the previous group of people leave, the staff will immediately release the mud in the pool and flush it with a high-pressure water gun. Because there were not many people and relatively empty, the staff asked which pool to choose. After the selection, they opened the valve to pour the mud and it was full soon. Then I told him for 20 minutes and walked away. The mud in the i-resort hot spring resort contains extremely high mineral silica. Slowly dive into the bottom of the mud pool to completely cover every inch of skin with the warm mud. The mud bath looks dirty, but after washing it will make the skin white and slippery. After washing up, soak in the hot spring, which is quite pleasant. Hot mineral mud baths, hot springs, and SPA are the essence of i-resort! So in the next 20 minutes, soak for a while. The mud is not as viscous as expected, but it's actually quite thin, but it's warm and comfortable. It almost came with a stopwatch. As soon as 20 minutes arrived, the staff came over, pointed at the watch, and then opened the valve at the bottom corner. The mud in the pool slowly lowered, and the neck, chest, and waist were gradually exposed. water surface. Bring a towel to wash, there is a special washing spray room for washing mud. After that, you can choose to soak in the hot spring pool, squint on the lounger, or go to eat. There are many places to kill time anyway. After sitting for a while, go to the SPA. In fact, you can also lie down and rest for a while, or take a foot bath. Give the ticket to the front desk, let's wait a moment, and arrange it. A waiter served hot ginger tea. The environment is okay, very quiet, with soothing background music, it's really relaxing, I feel like taking a nap. Loose bones, essential oils, pinch, massage, a set of procedures to walk down, feel refreshed, ears and eyes. If you have plenty of time, you can book a package for the water park, and there is a shuttle bus. Unless you bring children, you can play with the water in the hot spring pool. I went out to the gate and prepared to call a car to Zhongyu Shijiao. The receptionist asked me the direction to go, and took them to the parking lot of their resort. The 7-seater car, not from the taxi company, was the resort’s own car. The body has a LOGO and a meter. The condition of the car is very new. If you see the receptionist still recording the license plate and time with a notebook, just take it.

attractions.name: Long Son Pagoda
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Vietnam, Khanh Hoa, Nha Trang, Long Son Pagoda
attractions.address: Thai Nguyen St, Nha Trang, Vietnam
reviews: Long Son Pagoda, also known as Chua Long Son, is situated on the foothill of Trai Thuy Mountain in the city of Nha Trang. The temple is to be said open daily 24hour.

If you go for a walk up Yersin, through central Nha Trang you'll eventually find yourself at the Long Son Pagoda. Long Son is a Buddhist temple that suffered quite a bit of damage in the Vietnam war, but has since been brought back to its former glory. The temple itself can be found near the road, but for those wanting to experience some fantastic views of Nha Trang and its surrounds, take the stairs to the right (152, to be precise!) and you’ll find yourself at the foot of a massive statue of the Buddha. Keep an eye out for the young touts at the temple, as they will probably try and take you on a ‘free’ guided tour. While you’re not obliged to pay up, they WILL put the pressure on at the conclusion of the tour!

attractions.name: Intramuros
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Philippines, Metro Manila, Manila, Intramuros
reviews: Intramuros is historical place and is a good place to go if you want to have this spanish era vibe when visiting Manila.
Took a guided segway tour around the historic walled city with the family a few years back. Dinner after the tour at Patio de Victoria was so good.

This tour was the perfect blend of sight-seeing and exercise while learning about the history of the ancient Spanish Intramuros fort in Manila. Drinks afterwards at the Bayleaf Hotel while watching the sun set over the city was absolutely breathtaking :-D

Intramuros (La Ciudad Murada/ The Walled City) was capital of the entire archipelago during the 300-year rule of the Spaniards. Housing the provincial houses of the major religious orders, their schools, and the palaces of the civil government as well as large warehouses for Spanish trade goods and military ammunition, Intramuros was the center of the humongous Spanish Empire in Asia. If there is one sole original structure within Intramuros, it is none other than San Agustín Church, the only connection of any person to the history, art and culture of pre-War Intramuros. It is an exquisite repository of local Baroque designs and fixtures. Built in 1581, it is a UNESCO heritage site. If there is one museum in Intramuros you must visit, it is this one. Inaugurated in 1975 by the former Principe de Asturias (eventually King) Juan Carlos de Borbon and former Princess Sofía, it holds a vast collection of Augustinian and ecclestiastical arts and artifacts saved through the years. The former monastery gives visitors a veritable feel of the religious life in one of Intramuros’ seven convents, with its manicured gardens and patios, stone staircase and cloister or clausura lined with religious paintings. Plaza San Luis Complex. A reconstructed compound, it resembles a Spanish colonial residential enclave. Entering it gives you a semblance of what it was like to enter the mansions of pre-War Intramuros. Currently, it houses souvenir shops and Barbara’s, one of a few dining options in Intramuros. Although the Barbara’s in the upper floor is quite formal in set-up, you can enjoy a more relaxed dining experience at the first floor, surrounded by plants and white-washed stone walls. Sometimes, rondalla music would accompany you here. Manila Cathedral. Destroyed during the Liberation of Manila in 1945, the current building was rebuilt in 1958 through the efforts of the first Filipino Cardinal, Archbishop Rufino Cardinal Santos.

In the capital, Manila, in the heart of the city inhabited by Spanish colonists, stands a church that has survived earthquakes, typhoons, and wars. It has a history of 400 years and was listed in the world by UNESCO in 1993. St. Augustine on the heritage list.

attractions.name: Fort Santiago
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Philippines, Metro Manila, Manila, Fort Santiago
reviews: we need not travel far frommanila have an adventure. Located in the heart of Old Manila, Intramuros Manila (“within the walls” when translated literally from Spanish) is one of the Philippines’ biggest cultural and historical landmarks.The Walled City and its famous citadel Fort Santiago were the seat of government during the Spanish colonial period. Now, it is still very much a living, breathing city with universities, government offices, banks, hotels, and restaurants—and it is well worth the visit. The best part is you can enjoy most parts of Intramuros Manila without breaking the bank!

fort santiago is the actual prison cell where our National Hero Dr. Jose Rizal was imprisoned before his execution.  Being there will remind you of how nationalism lives in the heart of our historical heroes

As the place where José Rizal was executed by the Spanish colonial authorities, it's also of great historical

attractions.name: Manila American Cemetery and Memorial
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Philippines, Metro Manila, Manila, Manila American Cemetery and Memorial
attractions.open_status: Open from 9:00am-5:00pm;Closed during New Year's Day,Christmas
attractions.address: McKinley Road, Global City, Taguig 1220 Philippines
reviews: one of the greatest memorial i have ever been to !
A sobering monument & cemetery. Take the time to come out to BGC & see this magnificent & sobering cemetery.

It’s worth checking out. This place is for registering personal information. The cemetery is made up of American soldiers who died in the Philippine battlefield. The size and style are very similar to the Wellington International Cemetery in the United States. They are all white crosses, and all are covered. The most worth seeing of this place is the corridor on both sides of the two national flags in the center of the square. Here are some battle maps of important battles.

The Manila US Army Memorial Cemetery is free of admission, but you must register at the entrance to enter. A total of 17,206 American and Allied soldiers who died in World War II are buried here. It looks more like a park, with towering trees, and the carpet-like lawn is more beautiful than a golf course. Due to the high terrain, the noise is almost inaudible in the cemetery. On each cross, the name of a soldier who died was engraved. The tombstone for Christians is a cross, and for Jews, there is a monument in the center of the six-pointed star cemetery, and there is a horseshoe-shaped porch on the periphery with a map inlaid on it. In the map room, there are military materials and 25 exquisite maps, which witnessed the great victories of the US armed forces in the Pacific region, China, India, and Myanmar.

Knowing that there is a US military cemetery in the Philippines, I took a taxi to visit it. The doorman needs to register with passport information when entering the door. After registering, I started to enter, and I saw the white crosses standing on the green grass. It felt a little endless. Perhaps it was because I knew that they were the tombstones of soldiers. The shock was beyond words! Looking deeper, I saw the densely engraved names, time, etc. on the wall, as if they were all heroes standing in front of me!

Swayambhu is an ancient religious architecture atop a hill in the Kathmandu valley, west of Kathmandu city. The Tibetan name for the site means ‘Sublime Trees’, for the many varieties of trees found on the hill. A Tibetan monastery, meusum and library are more recent additions. The stupa has Buddha’s eyes and eyebrows painted on. The Swayambhunath Stupa also known as Monkey temple.

attractions.name: Bhaktapur Durbar Square
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Nepal, Bagmati, Bhaktapur, Bhaktapur Durbar Square
reviews: Very beautiful buildings, wood carving decoration is very special, many people in the square, take pictures to catch the empty, there are many worshippers, their national costumes are beautiful. Worth going 👍

If you want to find the deepest humanistic feelings in Nepal, the first choice is Badgang, the birthplace of art and architecture. Bhaktapur is more known as Bhaktapur in Nepal. As one of the three major cities, its existence carries the history and civilization of Nepal.

Badgang Durbar Square is the most expansive and clean of the three famous Durbar Squares. Apart from countless temples, the most attractive thing is the strong atmosphere of life of the locals. There will be a market here in the morning, usually starting around 6:00
The views are really good and well worth a visit.

The three major Durbar Squares in Kathmandu, the most informative, the largest, and the most worth visiting is Badgang Durbar Square, which is farther away from the Tamil area than the other two Durbar Squares. You can take the local place from Tamil. For buses, the drop-off point is the square ticket office. You can take a taxi if it is troublesome. With a Chinese passport, you can enjoy half-price tickets, 500 pesos. Only Badgang Durbar Square has a preferential policy for Chinese tourists. I bought the tickets and started to wander around slowly, taking pictures, just find a place to sit and chat with the locals when you’re tired, or you can go to Himalayan Java Cafe (Nepalese version of Starbucks) for coffee or Maserati, remember the king of yogurt , Yogurt served in a pottery bowl and eaten with a spoon must be clocked in.

attractions.name: Patan Durbar Square
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Nepal, Bagmati, Patan, Patan Durbar Square
reviews: Although Durbar Square in Patan is not as big as the squares in Kathmandu and Badgang, the old buildings are more dense and concentrated, and its architectural art is also very superb and exquisite. It occupies a place in the history of world architecture and is called "open-air museum". There is a market selling souvenirs and local specialties near the square, so you can visit and play together. Unfortunately, on April 25, 2015, a magnitude 8.1 earthquake occurred in Nepal, and most of the buildings in Patan Durbar Square were damaged. Among them, the Khalisanka Temple and the Charnarayan Temple completely collapsed, and the Yuganalandra ·The top statue of Mara King Pillar was dropped and damaged.

The Pigeon Square is surrounded by temples with big eyes. There are tens of thousands of pigeons. Here, the pigeon is the absolute master. The colorful flags are almost the same as the ones in Tibet. We can't see the difference. I don't know when it started, the colorful flags have become a standard religious symbol. Dogs on the roof is here. We saw a scene where the domestic dogs barked and wandered on the roof. No dog was led and bent on the road. This is a major feature. The world is so amazing!

1. Transportation strategy: There are two stations near the "Ratna Park" station in Kathmandu where you can take a minibus to Patan (NAC Bus Stop and Ratna Park Micro Bus Stop); 2. Patan Durbar Square is not very damaged by the earthquake Seriously, the most amazing "Nuvari-style buildings" are still well preserved, so there are a large number of tourists visiting, and the 1000 rupees tickets are also very strict; 3. The Royal Palace located in the center is also the Patan Museum. It is the focus of the visit, but if you are not particularly interested in Nepal’s emperor history or ancient architecture (especially for friends who travel poorly), you don’t need to enter the palace and just take pictures outside.

Durbar Square in Patan is the most exquisite square I have seen in Nepal. On one side of the square, the Patan Museum and the palace courtyard stand side by side. The eight buildings on the square are lined up one after the other, like a palace of the gods.

If you look for a good angle, there are still many places where you can take good photos, mostly red brick buildings. The earthquake loss in Nepal that year was really heavy. Many buildings were damaged, but the tickets were increased. .

Nepal is a good place, a country of mountains, with mountains that are almost everywhere right in front of your eyes, followed by valleys and rapids, and there are good places for drifting everywhere, where people enjoy the gifts of mountains.

Nepal is a mountain country. There are mountains everywhere, and all the houses in the long and narrow ravines are their own homes. One of the buildings here is the National Museum of Nepal, where you can see the history of Nepal.

attractions.name: Aspendos Antik Tiyatrosu
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Turkey, Mediterranean Region Turkey, Antalya, Aspendos Antik Tiyatrosu
attractions.address: Sarıabalı Mahallesi, Aspendos Yolu, 07500 Serik/Antalya, Turkey
reviews: This is the ancient upper man's entertainment city, the stage for human life

This theater can seat 7,000 people, and there are even VIP seats in the front row, which is quite elegant. It is also the most complete ancient Roman theater to date. The magnificent theater naturally retains very good musical effects, and it is surprising that this ancient theater is still in use every summer. Climbing to the top of the theater, there is indeed a sense of being condescending.

The Aspendos Amphitheater is the best-preserved Roman theater in Turkey. The main stage and stand here are quite well preserved. Concerts are often held here. It is amazing that the ancient Roman architecture is How durable, and the scientific design of the architect at that time, really had to admire the wisdom of the ancients.

This is the most preserved ancient Roman theater so far, and is still used. In Turkey saw three such theaters, Antalya one, Pamukkale one, and one here. Compared with this, it is the most magnificent. There were no audio equipment, but I stood on the high steps, and my friends were underneath, telling me I could hear you clearly.

If you go to romantic Turkey, you must go to Antalya, a Mediterranean resort in southern Turkey. Antalya is the most beautiful region in Turkey, located on the Mediterranean coast and surrounded by countless mountains. During the period of the Eastern Roman Empire and the Ottoman Empire, it was an important port in the Eastern Mediterranean. And 40 kilometers away from Antalya, there is one of the most intact ancient Roman "Aspendos" theater ruins in the world so far. After nearly 2000 years of sandstorms, it still stands majesticly there. . I was very surprised. The ancient Turks were able to build such a majestic building more than 2,000 years ago. It really is: I don’t know it, I was surprised at first sight! Admire it and like them!

attractions.name: Antalya Museum
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Turkey, Mediterranean Region Turkey, Antalya, Antalya Museum
reviews: In the Antalya Archaeological Museum, the correct posture for visiting the museum is unlocked. The statues of the figures naturally have interesting possibilities. The most favorite thing to see in the museum is the works of the figures, whether it is an oil painting or a sculpture.

The museum contains objects from the seven thousand years BC to the ancient Greco-Roman period. The most impressive is the Lachrymatory, which is used to collect the tears of a woman and give it to her sweetheart. It also often appears in the tomb. Worth coming!

The light source and display in the museum are not as meticulous as the Acropolis Museum, but a large number of sarcophagi are located in the center of the exhibition hall, which can be shuttled freely, realizing that the lifelikeness of each character in the story is its true meaning. Worth seeing!

The Antalya Museum The Antalya Museum is a first-class museum in Turkey. The historical relics exhibition hall contains ancient relics, unearthed objects from the Phoenician colony, and ceremonial demonstrations of funeral ceremonies. It is very different from domestic museums. The statue area of the gods is the highlight of the museum, with a large collection of works from the 2nd century. The art exhibition hall contains small artworks and shipwreck relics. There are several small ornate silver statues and ivory statues, which were excavated from ancient tombs in the 8th century. In the imperial hall, there is a Roman marble bust unearthed from the Baiji site, dating from the 2nd to the 3rd century AD. It is very well preserved. The museum has 13 exhibition halls, a children's exhibition area and an open-air exhibition area. All exhibits are cultural relics discovered locally, arranged in chronological order and different themes. The mosaic and portrait exhibition hall is very exciting, the ticket is 20 lire, and the audio guide is only 15 lire in English. It is recommended to rent a Chinese voice navigation to understand the long history of the Ottoman Empire.

The most unexpected is the Antalya Museum, which is shocking, with such a low-key appearance and not many people. Walking to the statues of the gods, against the dark red background wall, looking up at them, my heart rises in awe. Worth seeing!

The crowds here can also be quiet, you can enjoy the sea view against the backdrop of the ancient buildings, or you can enjoy yourself and enjoy yourself. Life here really doesn't want to go.

Antalya is Turkey’s Gulangyu in my heart. A small old town with dense buildings. If you look down at the city from the side of the road, you will feel like the red tiles, green trees, blue sea and blue sky, although those characters describe Qingdao. Walk down the streets of the old city under the scorching sun during the day, and feel the different life of the old city after nightfall. There are many bars where you can make it, and the soliciting guys invite you to drink Turkish apple tea.

We came here by taxi from outside the hotel. The driver brought us here and stayed with us for 4 hours, introduced us to Duden Falls, and then sent us back. The old town is beautiful. Be sure to wear a pair of comfortable shoes and walk around the block. Worth coming!

A beautiful picturesque town with many beautiful buildings, shops and cafes. The seaside scenery is breathtaking. There are many beautiful sights to see and many things to do here, and you can easily spend a day strolling. Don't miss it, it's worth a visit!

attractions.name: Side
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Turkey, Mediterranean Region Turkey, Antalya, Side
reviews: The ancient city of Side is the largest Roman city ruins in Antalya. It was built on the edge of the Mediterranean Sea. Now there are still several temple pillars and remains of the city wall. Looking at the scale, it is very large. How prosperous, but now there are only ruined walls, which makes people sigh the vicissitudes of history.

The famous ancient city on the Mediterranean Sea, because of its proximity to the sea, does not seem so vicissitudes and history, but reveals a fresh side different from other ancient cities. On the one hand, it is visiting the ancient city to feel the precipitation of history, on the other hand, it is the local customs that is blowing through the alleys with the sea breeze.

The ruins of the ancient Roman city-state in Antalya! Located on the Mediterranean coast, a large-scale ancient city site! Come here, see many tall Roman columns, Colosseum ruins, etc., stop and go and feel the civilization of ancient Rome!

Classic ancient Roman castle ruins! Located in Antalya, Turkey, the remaining buildings have been baptized by the years. There are not many tourists here. They can walk freely in the ancient city and reminisce about the prosperity of the ancient city!

There is an ancient city of Side near the coast of Antalya, Turkey, which is the ruins of an ancient Roman city state! When you come here, although the buildings here are ruins, you can still feel the charm of ancient Roman architecture!

The Grand Palace (Thai: พระบรมมหาราชวัง,RTGS: Phra Borom Maha Ratcha Wang) is a complex of buildings at the heart of Bangkok, Thailand. The palace has been the official residence of the Kings of Siam (and later Thailand) since 1782. The king, his court, and his royal government were based on the grounds of the palace until 1925.King Bhumibol Adulyadej (Rama IX), resided at the Chitralada Royal Villa and his successor King Vajiralongkorn (Rama X) at the Amphorn Sathan Residential Hall, both in the Dusit Palace, but the Grand Palace is still used for official events. Several royal ceremonies and state functions are held within the walls of the palace every year. The palace is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Thailand.
The dazzling, spectacular Grand Palace is undoubtedly the most famous landmark in Bangkok.The first construction ever started on year 1782. It's one must-see sight.

attractions.name: Dream World
attractions.loc_tags: Asia, Thailand, Bangkok, Dream World
reviews: Dream World Bangkok is a classical European-style amusement park which is full of tiny versions of the world's. Opened from 10 morning to 05pm for visits.

Dream World is everybody’s place to unleash their childhood dream for adventure. It offers a wide array of rides, both extreme and chill ones. I’m not that adventurous when it comes to rides, but I was happy to be there and will definitely go back.
nice environment, enjoyed the rides, quiet place.
Good place for fun with family

Although the area of Dream World in Bangkok is small, there are more than 40 kinds of entertainment facilities, which basically meet the needs of individual age groups, especially middle and children. . . The following are some of the'preparation matters' that we want to share with netizens after we play in the park: -1) The three months from March to June are the dry season in Bangkok, with an average temperature of 35 degrees or a body temperature of more than 40 degrees. Above, in order to prevent the skin from being'burned' by the'strong' ultraviolet rays, it is necessary to apply sunscreen to yourself or children. 2) When playing in the park, it is also recommended to wear sun protection gloves and a ‘cap’ on your arms. 3) Bring a small umbrella, after all, umbrellas can not only block the rain, but also shade. 4) "Physique" friends who like to attract mosquitoes also suggest not to miss the mosquito repellent. Although our trip did not provoke mosquitoes, after all, the park is an outdoor place, and we don’t need to find the body after returning to the hotel. 'Invaded' shamelessly by the hateful mosquito. . . 5) Don't'forget' to drink more water when playing. We suggest to play all the way from the right hand side of the map provided by the park (see attached picture), and then to the exit (or entrance) from the right hand side at the "end", so that basically all the play facilities can be covered , Travellers with children may wish to consider taking the children to take a few photo spots at the entrance to "souvenirs", then "play with the "water bike" on the 7th, and then come back to take the cable 5 that opens at 11 am The train and the No. 6 Dream World Sightseeing Train will not waste some time. Basically, there are not many tourists in the park, and the queue for individual rides generally does not exceed 10 minutes. . . Since the "entry ticket" provided by the park is a post with a number to be affixed to the clothes, the staff of the amusement park will roughly "check" before playing various amusement measures, so try to "protect" as much as possible, especially Water activities, although they usually see foreign tourists, they will be "accommodating", but after all, the "token" in hand, the heart is relatively secure. . . I hope this sharing can bring some help to travelers who are interested in visiting this park. I wish you a happy journey and a safe and smooth journey~~

Fantastic

March 8, 2019. This is the work of the French artist Jacques Majorelle, but it's the fashion industry leader Yves Saint Laurent who bought it as a private garden. Although Master YSL has been dead for many years, the garden remains largely the same. The garden has two main points: one is the extremely rich cactus and cactus ball varieties, which the Master YSL said he could find in the garden planted in the garden. Another look is "YSL blue", the garden inside the main building outside the walls of a very bright blue, said to be the YSL master personally tone color, to find this in all weather conditions are the most bright. YSL Blue outside the main building there are many rose-red flowers, take a beautiful tourist photo is a must. I also met Hong Kong tourists, other country meet compatriots, also take a photo together.

The gardens of Mayor are mostly designed for the famous Mayor blue, which is said to be derived from a plant in the Sahara, and the inspiration for the color of YSL nail polish No. 18 is also from the garden.

Although it is to go to the classic worship, that must not only use the mentality of grass-drawing to visit this park, because the park is not big, there are many tourists who queue up to take pictures, it is better to calm down to find a chair to sit down and feel the master's control of natural beauty.

attractions.name: Jemaa el-Fnaa
attractions.loc_tags: Africa, Morocco, Marrakesh-Safi, Marrakech, Jemaa el-Fnaa
attractions.address: Place de Marché Animée Jemaa el-fna by a-maps, 40000
reviews: crowded but funny place
It sucks! My worst travel experience ever! Everything is over price. Every vendor/shop owners will all pretend to be nice but once you don't buy they'll curse you or look at you badly.

It is a large 24-hour all-night market across the road from the Kutubiya Mosque, where almost all of the local Moroccan produce is found, and there are many people "selling, begging and distributing small advertisements" on the streets. The market's biggest charm is the night market, said to be Africa's largest, most lively night market. It's no exaggeration to say that even when the whole Marrakech is asleep, it's still lit and the people are boiling. It's fair to say that most of the fireworks in Marrakech are concentrated here. As the market is a mix of fish and dragons, safety is always a big issue, our guide was very opposed to our in-depth market tour. If you want to go in "exploration", be sure to be safe, keep your wallet in your pocket and don't talk to strangers

Jima Square is the essence of Marrakech. Foreign visitors can enjoy almost all of the Moroccan customs they expect: colorful folklore, grotesque lighting, unique food and drink, and of course, a gentle or sharp clash with the local people. As the sun goes down, the lights on the square gradually light up, this is the most beautiful moment in the square, from the high overlooking the entire square is a tourist must not miss the viewing experience. The night market is very rich in content, and our most interesting of course is the snack stall. Each food stall is marked with a number, but not in line with the choreography, the number may be far apart together, the same number even appear in different places, I think it may be the stall owners randomly choose a number of their own like it.
Be sure to try something cooked in Taji pots, such as lamb legs, which are pots of pottery and water-saving. The lids look like a pointed hat.

At the foot of the Atlas Mountains in the southern Atlantic Ocean, on the Tancift River in the Hauzi Plain, Morocco is said to be the world's largest earth city. It has been built for millennia, and was once called the City of Morocco, from which the country's name evolved. The city has changed hands many times in history because of its rich land, convenient transportation, rich wealth, and even the thousand years have not diminished its charm.

attractions.name: Bahia Palace
attractions.loc_tags: Africa, Morocco, Marrakesh-Safi, Marrakech, Bahia Palace
reviews: We arrived in January, the season is comfortable, there are not many tourists in the morning, and many people enter to visit and take pictures. It is very comfortable. The exquisite roof and wall mosaic patterns are beautiful and fresh. Interested people recommend visiting in the morning when there are fewer tourists.

The palace of Bahia is not too long ago, it is well protected, the building looks very new, a bit strange is that there is no furniture in the house. The stained glass windows are beautiful, and the interior is typical of the rich and colorful Moroccan style.

The entrance to the palace is not very different from the ordinary house, if it is not the door with the Moroccan flag, I would not have noticed it. The palace inside is relatively empty, no furniture decoration, only the building decoration itself, empty, it is difficult to imagine the bustling.
The Bahia Palace is said to be built by two Moroccan kings. It is very tall and is a deep passageway with narrow doors. The biggest feature is the mosaic and Arab flavor.

Came on March 7, 2019.

This palace was built at the end of the 19th century. It was built according to the goal of “the greatest palace in the world” at that time. Therefore, this palace is very luxurious. Even though the decorations in the palace have been removed, tourists only keep the hard decorations here. Can be seen.

The area of this palace is not particularly large, but the atrium is very large. There are several fountains of different shapes. The floors here are all covered with mosaics, which is not only magnificent but also elegant.

In addition to the appearance, the interior of the palace is also very elegant. The most representative one is the top and ceiling of a hall, which is composed of many mosaic decorations with different patterns. Each pattern is completed by a craftsman from the ancient city of Fez. In other words, how many patterns means How many craftsmen were requisitioned at that time.

Another highlight is the beautiful stained glass. It is estimated that Morocco had a high acceptance of European architectural styles at the end of the 19th century. In these stained glass interiors, you can take very artistic photos. I helped my wife to take a photo of "Waiting in the Boudoir", which was widely praised by the members of the tour group.

attractions.name: Palace Badi
attractions.loc_tags: Africa, Morocco, Marrakesh-Safi, Marrakech, Palace Badi
reviews: The only open palace in Morocco, hidden in a small street in the old town, is plain, if you want to know what the ancient palace in Morocco looks like? Then you can only go to Marrakech.

This is the oldest palace in Morocco. The word ruined wall is the only thing I feel when I see the Badi palace. Everywhere I look is the shock of red. There are many orange trees planted in the sunken garden of the palace, and the pool in the middle of the garden has no vitality, but when walking here, you can imagine the exquisiteness and beauty of its heyday. It must be a very beautiful palace.

60 tickets, covering a large area, although it is in ruins, you can vaguely see the former scale of Hongda. It is said that all the objects inside have been moved to the new palace. There is a prison connected to the palace, which has exhibitions about Morocco.

The beautiful palace ruins tell of the glory of the time. This place is very peaceful. It covers a large area and is very spacious, and the building is a masterpiece. If you want to visit here in full, it takes a lot of time. There is a museum (free). There is also a sermon history of Koutabia Monastery, but an extra ticket is required.

The Badi Palace means an unparalleled palace in Arabic. Today, only ruined walls are left here, and many white storks are nesting here. The scale of the palace is quite large, with a large pool in the middle, and the city gate platform has a good angle to enjoy the panoramic view of the city.

attractions.name: Gornergrat
attractions.loc_tags: Europe, Switzerland, Valais, Zermatt, Gornergrat
reviews:
The best place to see the majestic nature of the Matterhorn is the Gornergrat Observation Deck.
From Zermatt station, take a cogwheel train, after 35 minutes to the end, you will see the observation deck.
From the observation deck at an altitude of 3092 meters, you can see the 38 peaks of the Alps 360° from 360°. The most spectacular is the Matterhorn Peak. Looking down, the Gorner Glacier is white, which is too shocking~

Switzerland is a romantic country, and the Matterhorn is the symbol of Switzerland.
It is located in the small town of Zermatt in Switzerland. After getting off the train, you can take a small mountain train from the visitor center opposite to Europe's first viewing platform ~ Gornergrat to see the spectacular Matterhorn.

When you come to Zermatt, you must go on a mountain train! A very worthwhile project and also a rare experience. The Matterhorn can be seen from all angles along the way. It is very beautiful. The pass can be half price. If it is not winter, you can stop and hike. Winter lake freezes. 3100 meters to the top, there is a memorial wall. Those who like skiing can go down from the top and sit up again. It must be fun

[Sightseeing Raiders] Background: Start with the Matterhorn, a beautiful mountain in Zermatt, Switzerland, at 4,478 meters above sea level, which is a symbol of Switzerland's pride and the Alps, and the most famous image of the famous Swiss triangle chocolate. Zhi. To see the Matthong Peak, go to Zermatt first, this is the winter ski resort in southern Switzerland, a small city that does not pass cars, only passes trains, to Zermatt, opposite the train station is the station of the mountaineering train, here you can take Gornergrat Bahn up the mountain to see the Matthong Peak. The Gornegrat Railway (Gornergrat Bahn) is a mountain track railway, one end is the center of Zermatt town, the other end is the Gornegrat observation platform, which is 3089 meters above sea level and is the second highest open-air train station in Europe after Jungfrau. It is also the best platform to view the Matterhorn, basically the first time to Zermatt is a must. Traffic Raiders: Gornergrat BahnThe mountaineering train station is right next to the Zermatt Railway Station (Note that this is two different train stations.) Opening time: The mountaineering train has a timetable, basically starting at 7:00 in the morning, and the last train is 6, 7:00 in the afternoon when you come back. Winter and summer time is not the same, must see the time clearly, and hurry back to Zermatt before the last train, otherwise it will be miserable. Of course, there are several good hotels on the halfway up the mountain, if you can't come back, stay in the hotel, in case there is no room, sleep in the snow. Ticket price: Remember it seems to be 94 Swiss francs, if there is a Swiss pass to discount, this price can be hop-on hop-off, convenient for tourists to go down at each stop to see the scenery, or a short hike. Highlights: Besides Zermatt, the train stops five stops, and it's a ski resort in winter, and many people from all over Europe take all their skiing gear up and down, even in April, when the snow is all over the mountain. It's a hiker's paradise in summer, and Switzerland does make a special trip. The five stations are the Findelbach, Riffelalp, Riffelberg, Rotenboden and Gornergrat. When it is snowy in winter, the first two stops are mainly skiing, and the scenery is nothing special compared to the top. The third stop is Riffelberg, which has a super red hotel Riffelhaus 1853( River House 1853. The reason for this hotel's red is the outdoor SPA pool in the snow, which can enjoy the spa and watch the Matthong Peak. (I will also send a post about this hotel.) The second last stop, Rotenboden, is also famous, especially in summer, when it's not too far down the hill from the lake, which is not big, but the reflection of the Matterhorn on the surface and the green grass on the lake's edge make for a beautiful landscape. Many photographers and beautiful women are drawn to the train. But the ice on the lake in winter doesn't exist. The train seems to be coming twice to see the different views of the Matterhorn in winter and summer. The last stop is the viewing platform, there is a large building, inside the observatory, restaurant, chapel, even a hotel (this hotel may be the highest in Europe, the environment is average, although high but not net red, the price more than 2000 is not cheap. Personally recommend the Riffelhaus above. Tourists can take a square break and have lunch or something. From here, I feel close to the Matterhorn Peak, and of course I can also enjoy the Alps glacier Gornergletscher and the continuous snow mountain, all of them are snow-capped, very spectacular. Small Tips: It's much easier to get down. Many locals ski down. In the summer, they hike down to the middle of the mountain. The scenery is beautiful and not very tired. However, most people get down by train. Entertainment experience: When you reach the top of the mountain three kilometers, some people may have a high altitude reaction. Because they basically take the mountain train, so the physical effort is not too much. This is much better than the domestic mountain climbing, which is basically walking. Many cable cars come down with a lot of roads to walk, (such as Huangshan), and the experience is not good. If you are like the Swiss Matterhorn or Jungfrau, the transportation can drive directly to the viewing attractions, even if it is more expensive, I believe that it can attract many tourists.

The best angle to see the Matterhorn. From Zermatt Railway Station, take the cogwheel mountain train to the terminal. The round-trip price is 45 Swiss francs with the pass. In the middle, you can get off the bus and go around the station and then continue to ride, but each ticket gate can only enter and exit once. The top of the mountain is mainly a viewing platform and restaurant, but there will be many people getting off at the Rotenboden station just before the terminal because it is the most convenient place to see the reflection of the Matterhorn on the lake. After getting off the bus, walk along the road signs for 5-10 minutes and you will be in front of a small lake where you can see the reflection, preferably on a windless day.

attractions.name: Matterhorn Glacier Paradise
attractions.loc_tags: Europe, Switzerland, Valais, Zermatt, Matterhorn, Matterhorn Glacier Paradise
reviews: Take the cable car to the Matterhorn Glacier Paradise, first get off at the 6-person small box Furi station, then transfer to a large box car to Trockenter Steg station and then transfer to another large box car to Matterhorn Glacier paradise, there are two year-round snow under the glacier paradise The difficulty is not too high for skiing, the viewing platform is 3889 meters above, and you can see the Alps in the Italian border. The round trip cable car costs 100 Swiss francs.

Drive to trasch railway station and take the train to zermat. The local tyrant’s method is to use paragliders and helicopters, with more than 1,000 soft coins per capita. The middle class method is the cable car. There are also many cable car lines, there is always one suitable for you. In view of the status quo of the stock market, we have been beaten back to the Diaosi prototype, so we adopt the most primitive way of walking. Of course, there is also a way to force the frame to synchronize with the plane and the paraglider but to abuse itself, namely the bicycle. In view of the fact that the Swiss are all athletes, although we are a big country with gold medals, we still cannot compare with them. It was only two and a half hours, so I couldn't visit the highest peak, but I saw her mystery from different angles. The mystery is mainly caused by clouds and fog. There are several roads for climbing in the village. The biggest surprise is the cabins along the way. Switzerland is actually a mountainous country with small wooden houses dotted in the mountains and flowers dotted outside the wooden houses. This is probably love of life. Those who are walking through the mountains and have to ride on a flat surface or climb on a stone naturally have a sickly love of life, haha. Another accident was that the neck was covered with plateau red, like a red necklace. It has been 4 days and it hasn't gone down yet.

I saw the reflection of the snow-capped mountains on the lake online. It was very beautiful. I went to see it hopefully, but I was disappointed because I went too early. In April, it was still icy and snowy, and the lake was completely covered in snow. But the photos of the snow scenes I took are still beautiful, and I saw a lot of skiing dolls. They still need an adult report when they get off the car. But they are as light as a swallow when skiing and very cute.

Spectacular! It is recommended to wear sunglasses! I was dazzled by the snow ❄️, haha I will definitely come to ski next time! It is very fun to see many foreigners skating. I heard that they can slip from the border of Italy to the border of Switzerland. It is a very comfortable journey. The small cable car goes all the way to the top of the mountain. The pictures are beautiful! The underground ice room is also beautiful

The Matterhorn glacier paradise is the place with the most Swiss characteristics in my opinion. The happy Swiss people, old and young, skilfully slide down the high snow peaks with a pair of skis, so we can only be on the cable car. Watching the Chinese old people look at the snow and sigh. But the scenery is really good. You can watch the Matterhorn up close, which is really majestic.
